com.analog.lyric.collect

Interface ReleasableIterator<T>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.util.Iterator<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    EventSourceIterator, OptionParentIterator, ReleasableArrayIterator, SkipMap.Iterator, SkipMap.KeyIterator, SkipMap.ValueIterator, SkipSet.Iterator, UnmodifiableReleasableIterator

    public interface ReleasableIterator<T>
extends java.util.Iterator<T>
    An Iterator that can release itself to be reused. These iterators are expected to be used to avoid excessive allocation and garbage collection in cases where many iterations are being performed.

    Typical implementations will stash a reusable copy of the iterator in a variable, which will be nulled out when the iterator has been handed out but not yet released. Here is a partial example using a ThreadLocal variable: 

         public class FooIterator implements ReleasableIterator
     {
         private static final ThreadLocal resusableInstance = new ThreadLocal();
 
         public static FooIterator make(FooContainer c)
         {
             FooIterator iter = (FooIterator)FooIterator.reusableInstance.get();
             if (iter != null) {
                 FooIterator.reusableInstance.set(null);
                 iter.reset(c);
             } else {
                 iter = new FooIterator(c);
             }
         }
 
         public void release()
         {
             if (FooIterator.reusableInstance.get() == null) {
                 this.reset(null);
                 FooIterator.reusableInstance.set(this);
             }
         }
 
         // Reset iterator to start of contents of container.
         public void reset(FooContainer c)  ...
     }
    Other possible caching techniques include use of a static AtomicReference or to cache a reusable instance in the instance of the class that is responsible for creating the iterator.
    See Also:
    ReleasableIterable

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void release()
      Release this iterator so that it can be reused instead of being garbage-collected.

      • Methods inherited from interface java.util.Iterator

        hasNext, next, remove

    • Method Detail

      • release

        void release()
        Release this iterator so that it can be reused instead of being garbage-collected. The caller must not invoke any other methods on this object after releasing it.
